intro: Abutilon darwinii var. trinerve, commonly known as the Darwin's abutilon, is a species of flowering plant in the mallow family. It is native to South America, particularly Argentina and Chile, and is characterized by its distinctive, three-veined leaves. The plant produces showy, lantern-shaped flowers that are typically yellow or orange in color. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for ornamental gardening. Its unique foliage and vibrant blooms make it a valuable addition to both natural and cultivated landscapes.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon darwinii var. trinerve is primarily native to South America, specifically Argentina, Bolivia, and Paraguay. This variant is commonly found in the temperate regions of these countries. It thrives in areas with well-drained soil and moderate to warm climates. The plant is often associated with dry grasslands and shrublands. Its native distribution is largely confined to the southern part of South America.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon darwinii var. trinerve was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there during the 19th century as part of the botanical collections from South America. The plant is commonly found in coastal and disturbed areas, where it thrives in sunny, well-drained soils. It has become naturalized in certain regions and is considered a potential weed in some areas. Its introduction has raised concerns about its impact on native ecosystems.
